text: I'm playing around with the Julia lisp .scm parser files for a bit of fun. I've managed to mess about with some of the Julia parsing code, but everytime I make a change I have to recompile Julia. I'm fairly new to lisp and am enjoying playing with the parsing code way more that any lisp tutorial I've tried. What is the best way for me te set up a femto lisp environment where I can run all the Julia parsing code without having to compile Julia. How do others interactively debug their new Julia syntax?

text: Typically, after you have compiled Julia once, recompiling should be really fast if you only made changes to the lisp code

elements.text: Typically, after you have compiled Julia once, recompiling should be really fast if you only made changes to the lisp code

text: Also, if you are playing around in the femtolisp repl, I can pass on the recommendation of using `rlwrap`, since it will make `julia --lisp` much nicer to use

elements.text: Also, if you are playing around in the femtolisp repl, I can pass on the recommendation of using

text: It seems like it depends on where I make the edit in the lisp code. Sometimes it compiles only a little part (40 ish seconds) sometimes it compiles everything after a single scm edit (a few minutes).
